awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multi-Scale Micromechanical Properties of Hierarchical Coatings and Interfaces Fabricated by Self-Limiting Electrospray Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
Porous materials are ubiquitous in applications ranging from filtration and construction to ones in extreme environments, such as the Arctic, deep sea, and space.  The methods of manufacturing these materials often require bulk processing techniques, and it can be difficult to deterministically tune the structure and composition independently.  This collaborative research employs self-limiting electrospray deposition (SLED) to create controlled libraries of porous microfilms, enabling rapid screening of their characteristic material and architecture parameters while facilitating customized property tunability.  Mechanical analysis covering testing conditions from quasi-static to ballistic impact at room or elevated temperatures are undertaken, allowing probing of the materials’ mechanical response to thermomechanical stimulus.  For ballistic analysis, laser-induced particle impact testing (LIPIT), an innovative method of using laser-propelled microparticles to create controlled microballistic impact, is used.  These experiments inform a semi-empirical model that in turn guides the direction of future experiments, ultimately leading to a platform to design and optimize porous materials for myriad applications, including exploration of SLED thin films as low-thickness alternatives to bulkier coatings.  The project team consists of experts in SLED fabrication, nanomechanical testing and modeling, and microballistic analysis. This award allows for a new level of understanding and control of the synthesis of critical porous materials aiding in US competitiveness and prosperity. 

SLED utilizes the repulsion of the charged electrostatic spray to create level thin films of controlled thickness.  Spray parameters control different aspects of the final porous morphology.  The flow rate controls the characteristic scale of the porous structure; the solids loading controls the fill fraction of the pores; the spray temperature controls the degree of fusion of the pores; and the materials selection controls the composition of the material.  Evaluation of model plastic with and without particle and rubber reinforcement, along with crosslinked porous epoxies, will be performed.  During the strain rate testing in LIPIT, a ceramic microsphere is accelerated to at most 1,000 m/s by laser-induced rapid gas expansion and is tracked using ultrafast stroboscopic microscopy. An intense mechanical impulse is thereby applied to the specimen through the collision of the microsphere and can then be analyzed for energy dissipation and damage mechanisms. Moreover, using slower mechanical stimuli methods, nanoimpact (1-20 mm/s) and nanoindentation (10-1,000 nm/s), on the same specimens allows comparison between the deformation-rate-dependent characteristics of the SLED coatings over the different ranges.  Each stage of these studies is supported by multiscale computational simulations to create predictive models to guide both the course of the experiments and the design of future materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The primary goal of this project was to leverage the high-throughput nature of self-limiting electrospray deposition (SLED) to create libraries of porous polymer samples of different structure and composition for mechanical testing. Using a model glassy polymer, polystyrene, we were able to evaluate mechanical properties of different characteristic length scales over several orders of strain rate magnitude through nanoindentation, quartz crystal microbalance, and, through our collaborative award, microballistic impact. We were able to demonstrate that we could create coatings with tunable bulk static mechanical properties that were highly dynamically dissipative, all from a commodity material. Further, by exploring the compositional space of polymeric materials, we were able to create coatings of glassy materials that were reinforced with rubber inclusions or chemical crosslinks, tuning the quasistatic properties over a large range of stiffness and plasticity. Through SLED of such durable porous composites, we were able to create single-step, no-touch separators by SLED of porous polyimide coatings directly onto Li-ion electrodes. These separators possessed comparable performance to existing standard materials, but in a materials system that could sustain much higher temperatures. We were also able to demonstrate SLED of nanoparticle composites to tune mechanical and other functional properties, including the upgrading of off-the-shelf capacitive electronics to supercapacitors. Critical to these studies was expanding the capabilities of SLED as a materials manufacturing platform. We were able to determine the extend to which materials that would not be compatible with SLED, specifically plasticizers and crosslinking agents, could be blended into a compatible spray material without losing compatibility in the composite. This laid the groundwork for future studies in the true limits of materials that could be utilized in SLED by elucidating the importance of mass transport in charge dissipation during electrospray processing. We also reported a new, non-destructive method for measuring the thickness of thin films with highly optical scattering, that, when combined with microreflectometry, was essential for obtaining the thickness and porosity of the samples we evaluated without having to rely on costly, time-consuming electron microscopy.

Broader Impact: The understanding expansion of materials compositions that can be employed in conformal electrospray coatings is essential in standing up this technology as an alternative to dip coating or vacuum phase methods for microcoatings. In the duration of this grant, we have identified opportunities in the creation of supercapacitive devices, application of vaccines to microneedle arrays, the creation of separator membranes for batteries, and the application of superhydrophobic surface treatments. This in turn has created opportunities for technology transfer, including a licensed patent application. Further, together with another NSF Advanced Manufacturing award and NSF National I-Corps program, the research supported by this grant led to the receipt of multiple private grants/fellowships that supported the formation of a start-up company, Plumajet, Inc., which aims to commercialize our electrospray deposition technology. Results were also disseminated in multiple public presentations and posters and seven peer reviewed journal articles or conference proceedings.

There have also been considerable opportunities for student training, with both graduate and undergraduate student trainees participating actively in the project, and outreach. Most notably, this project supported the development of demonstrations at the annual Rutgers Day exposition, where we provided edible electrosprayed samples to hundreds of campus visitors.

 


Last Modified: 01/20/2025
Modified by: Jonathan Singer

There have also been considerable opportunities for student training, with both graduate and undergraduate student trainees participating actively in the project, and outreach. Most notably, this project supported the development of demonstrations at the annual Rutgers Day exposition, where we provided edible electrosprayed samples to hundreds of campus visitors.
